body.header: What will I learn in this unit?
body.section:
Monologue (social context)You will listen to a talk about writing a CV.
Conversation (educational context)You will listen to a tutor and two students discussing changes in women's employment.
Question typesYou will attempt four question types.Form completionMultiple selectionMultiple choiceSentence completion

section.p: You are usually given a form that needs to be filled in with personal details or other factual information using information from the listening text.
Read the instructions carefully. They will usually state that your answer should be NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS OR A NUMBER. But check this is the case.
Read through the form and decide what you need to listen for. Forms will often require details like names and addresses. Take note of any headings.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers.
Complete the form as you listen. The information will be given in the same order as the spaces in the form.
Use the words you hear, not your own.
Remember as you write, the answer could be a number, one word, two words or three words but not four words or more.
If you think you need more than three words your answer is probably incorrect.
You are given a question and six or seven possible answers from which you must choose three or four answers.
Read the instructions carefully. Check how many letters you need to circle.
Look at the vocabulary of the questions and try to work out what you are going to hear.
Underline the key words in the questions.
Decide what you need to listen for.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers.
If you don't know the meaning of any of the words in the questions look at the other questions and possible answers. They might have some associated vocabulary in them to help you guess the meaning.
Answer the questions as you listen.
You may hear all the words or phrases in your answer choices. Listen carefully for items rejected or selected.
Don't leave any questions unanswered.
Make sure you have selected the correct number of answers.
You are given a question and three or four possible answers from which you must choose one.
Read the instructions carefully. Make sure you only have to circle one letter.
Look at the vocabulary of the questions and try to work out what you are going to hear.
Underline the key words in the questions.
Decide what you need to listen for.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers. You may be able to eliminate answers too.
If you don't know the meaning of any of the words in the questions look at the other questions. They might have some associated vocabulary in them to help you guess the meaning.
Listen out for words of similar meaning to words in the answer choices.
Answer the questions as you listen.
Don't leave any questions unanswered.
You will be given a number of incomplete sentences which you need to complete with information from the listening text. The sentences may be in a table.
Read the instructions carefully. They will usually state that your answer should be NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS OR A NUMBER. But check this is the case.
Read the sentences.
If the sentences are part of a table, check whether the questions are horizontal or vertical.
Try to work out what you will be listening to. Any headings or sub-headings given will help you.
Decide what you are listening for.
Try to work out what grammatical form should follow the last word given in the sentence. Make sure you read the stem of the sentence carefully.
Complete the sentences as you listen.
The information will be given in the same order as the questions although it may be expressed differently. Listen out for words or phrases of similar meaning to those in the sentence stems.
You may use your own words. Make sure your sentences are grammatically correct.
Remember as you write, the answer could be a number, one word, two words or three words but not four words or more.
If you think you need more than three words your answer is probably incorrect.
